Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.common

Class Check<T,​E extends Exception>

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.naturalis.common.Check<T,​E>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the object being checked
    E - The type of exception thrown if a test fails
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    IntCheck, ObjectCheck
    public abstract class Check<T,​E extends Exception>
extends Object
    Methods for checking preconditions. If you need to check just one precondition for an argument, you can use one of the static methods. If you need to check multiple preconditions for the same argument, you might prefer to use the instance methods instead. For example: 

     int i = Check.that(numChairs, "numChairs").gte(2).lte(10).intValue();

    Exception messages

    Some static methods only take the argument to be tested and the name of the argument, not a complete error message. For example: 

     Check.notNull(name, "name"); // -> error message: "name must not null"

    To provide a custom message, choose the overloaded method that takes message arguments: 

     Check.notNull(name, "Please specify a name", null); // -> "Please specify a name"
 Check.notNull(name, "Please specify a name", ""); // -> "Please specify a name"
 Check.notNull(name, "Please specify a %s", "toy"); // -> "Please specify a toy"

    (If the first message argument is null or empty, it is ignored. Any remaining message arguments are ignored as well.)

    Checking properties and changing the Exception type

    When using the instance methods you can not just check the argument itself, but also its properties. In addition, the instance methods also allow you the change the type of Exception being thrown (defaults to IllegalArgumentException). For example: 

     this.query = Check.that(query, "query", InvalidQueryException::new)
  .notNull()
  .and(QuerySpec::getFrom, x -> nvl(from) == 0, "from must be null or zero")
  .and(QuerySpec::getSize, GTE, MIN_BATCH_SIZE, "size must be >= %d", MIN_BATCH_SIZE)
  .and(QuerySpec::getSize, LTE, MAX_BATCH_SIZE, "size must be <= %d", MAX_BATCH_SIZE)
  .and(QuerySpec::getSortFields, CollectionMethods::isEmpty, "sortFields must be empty")
  .value();

    (See the and methods and the Relation and IntRelation interfaces.)

    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

      • index

        public static int index​(int arg,
                        int maxExclusive,
                        String argName)
        Throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if arg is less than zero or greater than or equal to maxExclusive, else returns arg. This is especially useful to test "from" arguments, which generally should be less than the length or size of the object operated upon.
        Parameters:
        arg - The argument The argument to test
        maxExclusive - The maximum allowed value (exclusive)
        Returns:
        The argument
        Throws:
        ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException

      • index

                        String argName)
        Throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if arg is less than min or greater than max, else returns arg. This is especially useful to test "to" or "until" arguments, which generally should be less than or equal to the length or size of the object operated upon.
        Parameters:
        arg - The argument The argument to test
        minInclusive - The minimum allowed value (inclusive)
        MaxInclusive - The maximum allowed value (inclusive)
        Returns:
        The argument
        Throws:

      • noneNull

        public static <T> T noneNull​(T arg,
                             String argName)
        Verifies that the argument is not null or contains any null values. The latter is applicable if the argument is an array, Collection or Map. For Map arguments only the values are tested, not the keys.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the argument
        Parameters:
        arg - The argument
        argName - The argument name
        Returns:
        The argument
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the argument is null or contains null values
        See Also:
        ObjectMethods.isDeepNotNull(Object)

      • badArgument

        public static Supplier<IllegalArgumentException> badArgument​(String message,
                                                             Object... msgArgs)
        Utility method returning a Supplier of an IllegalArgumentException with the provided message and message arguments. Useful as static import: 

         Check.that(year % 13 != 0, badArgument("Not a lucky year: %d", year));
        Parameters:
        message - The exception message
        msgArgs - The message arguments
        Returns:
        A Supplier of an IllegalArgumentException with the provided message and message arguments

      • and

        public <U> Check<T,​E> and​(Function<T,​U> getter,
                                Predicate<U> test,
                                String message,
                                Object... msgArgs)
                         throws E extends Exception
        Checks the value of a property of the argument. This allows you to check multiple properties of the same argument. For example: 

         this.employee = Check.that(employee, "employee")
    .notNull()
    .and(Employee::getFullName, s -> s.length() < 200, "Full name too large")
    .and(Employee::getHobbies, not(Collection::contains), "Partying", "Partying discouraged")
    .and(Employee::getAge, GTE, 16, "Employee must be at least 16")
    .value();

        You should do a notNull check on the argument first, because this method doesn't and assumes the argument is not null.

        Type Parameters:
        U - The type of the property
        Parameters:
        getter - A function that has the argument as its input and returns the value of the property
        test - The test
        message - The exception message
        msgArgs - The message arguments
        Returns:
        This Check object
        Throws:
        E - If the test fails
        E extends Exception
        See Also:
        Relation, IntRelation

      • andInt

        public Check<T,​E> andInt​(ToIntFunction<T> getter,
                               IntPredicate test,
                               String message,
                               Object... msgArgs)
                        throws E extends Exception
        Checks the value of a property of the argument. You should do a notNull check on the argument first, because this method doesn't and assumes the argument is not null.
        Parameters:
        getter - A function that has the argument as its input and returns the value of the property
        test - The test
        message - The exception message
        msgArgs - The message arguments
        Returns:
        This Check object
        Throws:
        E - If the test fails
        E extends Exception

      • and

        public <U,​V> Check<T,​E> and​(Function<T,​U> getter,
                                        Relation<U,​V> relation,
                                        V value,
                                        String message,
                                        Object... msgArgs)
                                 throws E extends Exception
        Verifies that the provided relation exists between some property of the argument and the specified value. For example: 

         Check.that(employee, "employee").notNull()
    .and(Employee::getFullName, String::contains, "Dicky", "Was expecting Dicky");

        You should do a notNull check on the argument first, because this method doesn't and assumes the argument is not null.

        Type Parameters:
        U - The type of the property
        V - The type of the object that the property must have some relation with
        Parameters:
        getter - A function that has the argument as its input and returns the value of the property
        relation - The relation to must exist between the property and the specified value
        value - The value that the property must have the specified relation to
        message - The exception message
        msgArgs - The message arguments
        Returns:
        This Check object
        Throws:
        E - If the relation does not exist
        E extends Exception
        See Also:
        Relation

      • and

        public Check<T,​E> and​(ToIntFunction<T> getter,
                            IntRelation relation,
                            int value,
                            String message,
                            Object... msgArgs)
                     throws E extends Exception
        Verifies that the provided relation exists between some integer property of the argument and the specified integer value value. For example: 

         Check.that(employee, "employee").notNull()
    .and(Employee::getId, GT, 0, "Id must be positive");

        You should do a notNull check on the argument first, because this method doesn't and assumes the argument is not null.

        Parameters:
        getter - A function that has the argument as its input and returns the value of the property
        relation - The relation to must exist between the property and the specified value
        value - The value that the property must have the specified relation to
        message - The exception message
        msgArgs - The message arguments
        Returns:
        This Check object
        Throws:
        E - If the relation does not exist
        E extends Exception
        See Also:
        IntRelation

      • value

        public abstract T value()
        Returns the argument being tested. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks. For example: 
         Integer i = Check.that(counter, "counter").notNull().value();
        Returns:
        The argument

      • intValue

        public int intValue()
        Returns the argument being tested as an int. If the argument being tested actually is an int rather than an Integer, this method saves the cost of unboxing incurred by value(). If the argument neither is int nor an Integer this method throws a ClassCastException.
        Returns:
        The argument cast or converted to an int
